titleStmt.title: The Queenes proceedings in Holland. Being the copie of a letter sent from the staple at Middleborough to Mr. Vanrode a Dutch marchant in London. Wherein is contained these sixe particulars following: First, the King of Denmarke his ambassadour comming to the Queenes Court at the Hague with a Message to the states of Holland, accompanied with the Prince of Orange. 2. Colonell Goring his raising of forces in Ortoys by commission from the K. of France, with a challenge from Colonell Gage unto Goring for his so doing. 3. What summes of money have been raised by priests, and jesuites, &c. throughout the cloisters in those provinces, with their severall names, &c. 4. What summes already have bin raised towards the maintenance of the Rebellion in Ireland, as also an Irish ambassador at Bruzels for a second supply. 5. The Bishop of Cullen his death. 6. The Prince of Orange his court at Breda.
titleStmt.author: Keeling, Josias.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
THE QUEENES Proceedings in HOLLAND. BEING The Copie of a Letter ≈øent from the Staple at Middleborough to Mr. VANRODE a Dutch Marchant in London. Wherein is contained the≈øe ≈øixe Particulars following:
Fir≈øt, the King of Denmarke his Amba≈ø≈øadour comming to the Queenes Court at the Hague with a Me≈ø≈øage to the States of Holland, accompanied with the Prince of Orange.
2. Colonell Goring his rai≈øing of Forces in Ortoys by Commi≈ø≈øion from the K. of France, with a Challenge from Colonell Gage unto Goring for his ≈øo doing.
3. What ≈øummes of Money have been rai≈øed by Prie≈øts, and Je≈øuites, &c. throughout the Cloi≈øters in tho≈øe Provinces, with their ≈øeverall names, &c.
4. What ≈øummes already have bin rai≈øed towards the maintenance of the Rebellion in Ireland, as al≈øo an Jri≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador at Bruzels for a ≈øecond ≈øupply.
5. The Bi≈øhop of Cullen his Death.
6. The Prince of Orange his Court at Breda.
LONDON. Decemb 30. Printed by T. F. for I. M. 1642.

div.head: The Copie of a Letter from the Staple at Middleborough in Holland, to Mr. VANRODE a Dutch Marchant in London.
div.p:
SIR, the ≈øixty odde pounds of Bever amounting neere upon 400. Rix Dollers J lately ≈øent you being intercepted and ≈øeiz'd on by the Kings Fleet, J ≈øhall be contented to beare an equall ≈øhare of the charge of Cu≈øtome, or by any other lo≈ø≈øe you ≈øhall ≈øu≈øtaine through the default of my Ship-ma≈øter or any of his in this behalfe, more J hope you will not de≈øire con≈øidering my unwillingnes in hazarding
it in the≈øe trouble≈øome times of danger, &c. wee might very well have ≈øtayed the tran≈øportation therof for one Moneth longer, which then might be ≈øafely tran≈øported and convoyed by five or ≈øix States men of Warre, which are all ready for the bringing over of an Amba≈øsador from the King of Denmarke to the King of England, he came to the Queens Court at the Hague upon the 20. of December, the Prince of Orange being at Breda, accompanied the Amba≈øsador all through the Countrey, and brought him to the Queenes Court, who was royally entertained, and intends forthwith to come for England, his Emba≈øsage to his Maje≈øty is privately concealed, onely this the K. of Denmarke de≈øireth the States of Holland, that they would bee plea≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the King with ≈øuch forces by Sea as ≈øhall be an≈øwerable to tho≈øe which he ≈øhall provide by Land, in warring again≈øt Tunis, Argier and other places, concerning a late breach of Pacification in detaining our Countrimen ≈øtill Captives and Slaves, though their Ran≈øomes have bin payd in a very large
contribution. Colonell Goring is travelled into Ortoys and Flanders to rai≈øe forces of Men and Armour, he having a Commi≈ø≈øion from the King of France to take a certaine number from each Garri≈øon, for the Queene and pre≈øent ≈øupply for England. Colonell Gage who is Colonell over the Engli≈øh in Flanders, gave Colonell Goring a Challenge for pre≈øuming to beat up his Drums to flock away his Officers and Souldiers, neverthele≈øse the ≈øouldiers being poore and long behind of their contribution mony agreed, and five or 600. Engli≈øh followed Colonell Goring to Dunkirke, Newport, O≈øtend, and Graveling, where they now remaine, till they be Shipt for England, there hath bin great meanes to the States that the≈øe Souldiers might bee permitted to pa≈ø≈øe through their Country and ≈øo take ≈øhipping for England, but the Queene nor the Amba≈øsador can prevaile with the States for their con≈øents therein. J have al≈øo here ≈øet you downe the ≈øummes of money rai≈øed among≈øt the Prie≈øts, Je≈øuites, Seminaries, Friers, Nuns, and holy Si≈øters through the land,
and paid in to the Je≈øuites of St. Omers his Colledge towards the maintenance of his Maje≈øties warres. And fir≈øt as in order the Engli≈øh Cloy≈øter at St. Omers, the Je≈øuits have rai≈øed 3000. pounds, be≈øides the Taxes they have impo≈øed upon every Scholler 5. l. a man being about 400. and that if any ≈øhall refu≈øe the payment thereof to lo≈øe their Degrees in the Hou≈øe, and be for ever di≈øcharged for having any future bene≈øit therein: in which Colledge the ≈øumme collected amounts about 3500. l. Secondly at Ayres, the ≈øumme collected amounts unto 500. l. Thirdly, at Beteone, the ≈øumme collected amounts unto 500. l. Fourthly at Arras, the ≈øome of 2000. l.
Fiftly at the Univer≈øity of Doway, 1000. l.
Sixtly at Gaunt, betweene the Colledge of Engli≈øh and Jri≈øh Prie≈øts, and the Matron of the Nunnes there, was Collected 500. l.

Seventhly at Durmount, 50. l. Eightly at Bruzels, from the Counte≈ø≈øe of We≈øtmorland, and the Lady Babthorpe, Matrons of the holy Nuns, and the three Cloy≈øters Engli≈øh, Jri≈øh, and Walloons, 3000. l. Ninthly at Lovain, 1000. l.
Tenthly at Bridges, 300. l. Eleventhlily at Ca≈øteele, 200. l. Twelfely at Newport, 200. l.

Thirteenth at O≈øtend, 100. l. Fourteenth at Graveling, 100. l. Fifteenth at Dunkerke, 500. l. all which ≈øummes amounteth about 15000. l. have bin Collected and in the hands of Father Browne the Head of St. Omers Colledges, be≈øides 5000. l. more gathered from the Governours of every Towne, Village, or petty Dorpe, which makes the ≈øumme of 20. thou≈øand pounds, all which is intended to be tran≈øported to his Maje≈øty from Dunkirke, be≈øides the weekely allowance the Colledges will disbur≈øe towards the maintenance of the five hundred Souldiers under the command of Colonell Goring, during his Maje≈øties warres with the Parliament.

The Rebels of Jreland have had al≈øo nere upon ≈øixty thou≈øand pounds already ≈øent them, & an Jri≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador is again ≈øent to Bruzels intreating the ≈øtate for more monies, which as yet we heare nothing of a ≈øecond ≈øupply. The great Bi≈øhop of Cullen is lately dead, which puts the Country in a great di≈øorder,
an Jtalian is ≈øince Cho≈øen. And thus much as J have ≈øet downe is the common di≈øcour≈øe at the Queenes court, and whither her Maje≈øty intendeth to goe over with the Denmarke Emba≈øsador is not certainly knowne, here is a great di≈øcention betweene the States and the Prince of Orange, which makes the Prince leave his Court at the Hague and continueth at Breda with One thou≈øand of hor≈øe and foot, & ≈øeldome or never comes to the Queenes Court though her Maje≈øty have often ≈øent for him, J cannot certifie more as this we ≈øhall remoove our Staple from hence to Delph.

closer.signed: Your obliged and tru≈øty friend, JOSIAS KEELING.
